Bad Moon Rising.passage:
[]
Bad Moon Rising is an American country-western song that was written by a former member of the American popular group "The Ozark Mountain Daredevils" called Jerry Lee Lewis. It was written by Johnny Thunders, Jerry Lee Lewis, Billy Graham, John Peel and Bill Price in 1971. The most popular version of the song is by American country musician Ozark Mountain Daredevils on their 1971 debut album, Ozark Mountain Daredevils, and has been recorded by numerous other artists. The song "Bad Moon Rising" [2] (also known as "Ain't No Sunshine") was originally titled "Ain't No Sunshine" by a former Ozark Mountain Daredevils member Johnny Thunders. It was written and performed by Thunders, his brother Jerry "J.R." Lewis and Billy Graham as "Ain't No Sunshine". They recorded the song under their own name on their album in 1970. In 1971, Jerry Lee Lewis covered the song, which was titled "Bad Moon Rising" in the U.K., and "Ain't No Sunshine" in the U.S., and released it as a single in early 1971. "Bad Moon Rising" was the title of the Ozark Mountain Daredevils song.

- Billie Jean (1938–1990), African-American singer-songwriter and performer, was born Anna Mae Bullock on March 8, 1933, in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Her mother was a former child actress who had two children in four years. Her parents divorced soon after her birth, when she was 7 years old. As a child she sang at home with her father, a Baptist minister, who, although he was not particularly religious, was also very involved in a Baptist Church choir in Philadelphia and encouraged his children to sing. She was inspired to sing at an early age and made a number of public appearances as a teenager. She entered a local talent show in Philadelphia in 1951 and, in 1954, had her first hit on a local label with the track "Me and Bobby McGee". Although a huge hit and widely distributed, it went largely unnoticed at the time of its release in 1954, until it was revived several years later and released on her second album for Mercury Records. The same year, she was signed to Atlantic Records after a label scout heard her perform in New York City. As a singer in the late 1950s, she was a member of the girl group, The Shirelles.

Bohemian Rhapsody.passage: Bohemian Rhapsody is a song by the English heavy metal band Queen. It is a complex song that is the longest of any of the band's songs and one of the most notable songs in the world of rock music. It is usually classified as a ballad, with a structure based on the form of a sonata, but with the lyrics of a regular pop song. It was co-written by two of the band's members, Freddie Mercury and Brian May. Bohemian Rhapsody was released in the UK in November 1975, reaching number one. It spent the next five years on the charts, and at the time of Mercury's death in 1985, the song had become a legend and a musical icon in Europe. The song is credited for bringing Queen a mainstream audience.

Anna Mae Bullock.passage: In 2000, Anna Mae Bullock was chosen as the greatest African American of the century in a BBC poll, narrowly edging out Malcolm X. Bullock was born in North Philadelphia, Pennsylvania on May 5, 1912, to the Bullocks. She attended the Philadelphia Industrial School for Girls (now known as Girls Prep). In her adult life, Bullock was a professional singer, singer-songwriter, actress, and also a painter. Her father, William James Bullock, was a labourer, and her mother, who was of West African and Native American descent, was a housemaid. Her parents divorced when she was 11. Her first notable role was that of the first female singer at Philadelphia's Cafe Society. After working with the singers Pearl Bailey and Billie Holiday, she sang in the band, the Royal Creole Orchestra. As a vocalist and an actress, she also toured with the band, Billie Holiday's Orchestra. By the 1960s, she was on tour across Europe. She toured with the famous jazz pianist, Nat King Cole, and in the United States with Lionel Hampton. Her acting career began with a bit part in the musical, "A Day for a Pig and a Monkey". She subsequently starred in many African-American films of the time. She appeared on Broadway in the musical, "A Day for a Pig and a Monkey", and also in the revival of "Porgy".

qae_pairs.question: What was the name of the orchestra that Anna Mae Bullock joined?

Philadelphia.passage:
"The city, which was once a capital of the British Empire, is now a capital of the United States of America. Philadelphia is located in the southeast corner of Pennsylvania. The city is situated in the Delaware Valley, along the Delaware and Schuylkill Rivers and at the foot of the Tacony Creek. In 1747, Philadelphia was established by William Penn, and it is now home to over 1.5 million people. Philadelphia is the birthplace of such famous American writers as Benjamin Franklin, John Locke, Robert Moray, William James and Edgar Allan Poe, and is home to one of the nation's most famous educational institutions, the University of Pennsylvania. Philadelphia was the largest city in the world in 1790, and remains a major port in the Delaware Valley." Wikipedia

Gloria Gaynor.passage: The "Gloria Gaynor" (also known as "The Gloria Gaynor Show" is the title of Gloria Gaynor's show from 1970 to 1976, during which period she became popular in the United Kingdom. The show, on its own merits, was a popular success with a loyal audience, and a series of three shows was recently revived at the Hippodrome in the UK, to great acclaim, on 10 August 2006, after a recent tour of New Zealand and other parts of the world. The show was revived and the original 1970-6 cast, including Barry Dunlop, Paul "B" Bannon, Sue Evans, Paul Gambill and Mick Jones, played to packed houses to an audience of 2.5 million. It received widespread praise, from critics in the British and American press. In her introduction, Ms Gaynor told of how she had written a song with Paul Dunlop, who was to become her co-producer on the show, when he was 22 and she was only 20. They performed as a duo at the Ritz club on London's Park Lane. The song she wrote for him was "You Should Be Dancing". Brian May.passage: "Brian May (Brian Matthew May, 19 May 1947, Sheffield, South Yorkshire) is a British singer, songwriter, guitarist, and drummer who, with Roger Taylor, founded the pop group Queen. May was originally an amateur trumpet player and singer, and, after joining Queen in 1971, was in charge of singing a number of songs in the group's early years, including "Bohemian Rhapsody". In later years he became known for his technical ability at playing the guitar, and the band's album A Night at the Opera won an award for Best Metal Performance at the 1979 Grammy Awards. May played guitar, sang and wrote songs on most of the band's later albums, and also wrote most of Queen's material, as well as a number of songs by the likes of John Peel, Oasis and Paul McCartney. In his musical career he also has been a prolific songwriter and solo artist. Although not a member of the band since 1991, he has remained in touch with the band members and his last album was made available in 1997 on EMI. May was the first lead singer to go solo from a band and has had a highly successful solo career, which has included albums and tours with both Paul McCartney and Oasis, as well as numerous collaborations with a number of artists from other genres.

Queen.passage:
“The Royal Commission was established in 1947, to inquire into the “financial, social, and administrative” workings of the Royal Family. It investigated the expenses of Prince Charles and Princess Anne and the role of the Royal Household. Although none of the recommendations of the Commission’s report were put into effect, it did increase the awareness of the Royal Household and Royal finance to the general public. This caused the number of “Royal watchers” to increase; from the 50,000 who regularly visited Buckingham Palace to a much larger number who became obsessed with the Royals. As a result of the commission’s investigations, it led to an increase in the interest of the public in the Royals, who began to become increasingly popular, leading to an increase in tourist numbers to the country.”

Led Zeppelin II.passage: I was listening to Led Zeppelin II today and in this song the drummer John Paul Jones is playing one of the most distinctive parts he played in that album (as far as I know). He plays a bass drum rhythm, then plays a crash-dotted cymbal rhythm that I would like to call a "hi-hat" rhythm, then he plays a very interesting fill that I would call a "fugue." It is a sort of a pattern or riddle for me to try to decipher which rhythm is playing and when. The hi-hat rhythm is on one measure of bars, the two rhythms are on the next and so on. When I first listened to this album I couldn't distinguish the hi-hat and the crash-dotted cymbal rhythm, but today I could. In addition, I can also now recognize a sort of "flourish" that I would call a sort of "counter-rhythm" that John Paul Jones plays. These are the most distinctive parts to me in this song, but in any way I know the drummer's parts is great. In addition, Robert Plant's singing and lyrics, in general, are great and he is a great singer. The drummer's parts is definitely a highlight.
